intro: Ramsdenia excisa, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Viscaceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and fleshy, sticky berries. The plant attaches itself to host trees, such as eucalypts, through its haustoria, drawing water and nutrients from the host. It plays an important ecological role in its habitat by providing food for birds and insects. However, it can also be considered a potential threat to the health of its host trees.
